I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Indonesia (the Government) has expressed its concern over the 
increasing level of vehicular emissions and the consequent environmental impact in Jakarta and 
other large urban centers. To address this situation, the program to phase out leaded gasoline 
commenced in July 2001 and the fuel prices are now linked to international prices to promote 
efficient  use.  Against  this  background  and  at  the  request  of  the  Government,  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  fielded  the  Fact-Finding  Mission  (the  Mission)  for  the  technical 
assistance (TA) for preparing the Clean Vehicle Fuel for Blue Skies Project (the Project) on 14–
16  May  2002. The  Mission  and  the  Government reached an understanding on the goals, 
purpose, scope, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of 
reference for the TA. A preliminary logical framework is in Appendix 1, and a summary initial 
poverty and social assessment in Appendix 2.1 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Rapid urbanization and industrialization in Indonesia have created severe air pollution 
problems, particularly in its major cities. The United Nations Environmental Program ranks 
Jakarta as the world’s third most polluted mega-city, after Mexico and Bangkok. Vehicular traffic 
emissions  are  obvious  and  major  sources  of  air  pollution.  An  ADB-funded  regional  TA2 
estimated that vehicle emissions in Jakarta amount to approximately 71% of the oxides of 
nitrogen (NOx), 15% of sulfur dioxide (SO ), and 70% of particulate matter (PM )3 in the total 
2 10
emission loads, and the annual economic cost of the associated health problems will be about 
$450 million by 2015. Another World Bank study4 estimated health damage due to all sources of 
air pollution in Jakarta at approximately $300 million per year in 1990, and this was projected to 
increase tenfold by 2010 unless serious control efforts were implemented.  
 
3.  In recognition of the growing severity of air pollution caused by industrial expansion, 
rapid urbanization, and increasing vehicle numbers, the World Bank started the Urban Air 
Quality Management Strategy (URBAIR) in 1992 as part of its Metropolitan Environmental 
Improvement Program, and an action plan was formulated. Following from this work, the Japan 
International Cooperation Agency (JICA) and Indonesia’s Environmental Impact Management 
Agency (BAPEDAL) (i) continued air pollution studies in the Greater Jakarta area from 1994 to 
1997, and prepared an air pollution control strategy for the period till 2010; and (ii) conducted an 
investigation and analysis of Jakarta’s socioeconomy, environment, meteorology, air quality, 
and air pollution sources, which enabled formulation of an action plan through to 2000.  
 
4.  Several critical components of the World Bank and JICA-supported action plans have 
been  implemented.  These  include  starting  to  phase  out  leaded  gasoline  in  July  2001, 
establishing a networking system and stations for ambient air quality in 10 Indonesian cities, 
and developing emissions standards for stationary and mobile sources. However, a number of 
important air pollution countermeasures proposed in the earlier studies have not yet been 
implemented effectively.

5.  The ADB regional TA (footnote 2) further funded a multisectoral group, Friends of Clean 
Emission (the MEB) to formulate a draft action plan for reducing vehicular emissions. The MEB 
is  a  voluntary  group  that  comprises  officials  and  representatives  from  the  Government 
ministries, city government, transport departments, police, fuel suppliers, transport industry, and 
civil society. The Ministry of Environment (MOE) coordinated the MEB’s activities and will need 
further technical and financial assistance to review and adopt, along with other concerned 
agencies,  the  action  plan;  formulate  policies;  and  establish  standards  and  guidelines  for 
vehicular emissions.   
 
6.  The MEB action plan identified five areas for direct interventions to reduce vehicle 
emissions in Greater Jakarta, (i) implementation of new vehicle emission and fuel standards, (ii) 
improvement of vehicle standard and technology (including installation of catalytic converters), 
(iii)  introduction  of  a  regime  for  inspection  and  maintenance,  (iv)  refinement  of  transport 
planning, and (v) management of air quality. The maximum reduction of vehicle emission loads 
in 2005 and 2015 will be possible by implementing new vehicle emission and fuel standards by 
assuring supply of cleaner fuels and lowering vehicular emission limits. The Government has 
promoted compressed natural gas (CNG) as a clean fuel since 1995 and increasing its use will 
significantly reduce emission load and thereby help improve the air quality in Jakarta. 
 
7.  Several  countries  have  introduced  natural-gas-driven  vehicles  to  address  urban 
pollution. These include Australia, Canada, Iran, New Zealand, Thailand, United Kingdom, and 
United States. More recently, CNG programs have been initiated in Argentina, Bangladesh, 
India, and Pakistan. ADB has approved two loans to develop the use of CNG for the transport in 
Dhaka.5 
 
8.  Natural gas is the cleanest burning fossil fuel and an improvement over other primary 
energy sources. Natural gas combustion results in virtually no atmospheric emissions of sulfur 
dioxide (SO ) or particulate matter (PM ); and 45-70% lower emissions of carbon monoxide 
2 10
(CO), reactive hydrocarbon, oxides of nitrogen (NO ) and carbon dioxide (CO ) than from the 
x 2
combustion of other fossil fuels. Use of CNG would contribute significantly toward improved air 
quality. Advanced technology used for natural-gas-fueled vehicles could further reduce carbon 
monoxide (CO) emissions by as much as 90% and reactive hydrocarbon emissions by about 
85%, compared to gasoline-fueled vehicles. 
 
9.  Indonesia is well endowed with natural gas reserves. During the past few years, about 
60% of natural gas production was exported as liquefied natural gas. However, given the scale 
of its gas reserves, Indonesia’s present domestic natural gas consumption accounts for about 
18% of total primary commercial energy supply only, which is among the lowest in Southeast 
Asia.  Domestic  use  of  gas  and  associated  infrastructure  are  underdeveloped  and  the 
environmental benefits remain unrealized. ADB is supporting gas infrastructure development in 
South Sumatra under the Gas Transmission and Distribution Project,6 which has successfully 
completed the first major gas transmission pipeline (about 510 kilometer) in Sumatra. Additional 
gas transmission pipelines are being constructed under the same project to supply natural gas 
from South Sumatra to Singapore.

10.  In 1995, the Government embarked on a reform process to increase development of 
natural gas resources and mobilize the required financing from the private sector for natural gas 
production,  processing,  and  transmission.  In  1995,  ADB  provided  a  TA7  to  support  the 
development of a corresponding gas sector policy and a regulatory framework, and its inputs 
were used in the new oil and gas law enacted by the Government in 2001. Another ADB-funded 
advisory TA is being implemented to prepare a comprehensive gas sector development plan 
that will guide and promote the development of Indonesia’s gas infrastructure over the next 5 
years so as to meet the expected increased domestic demand for natural gas; reduce the 
consumption  of  imported  and  exportable  substitute  fuels,  and  the  environmental  impacts 
associated with the use of such fuels; and promote increased small-scale production and use of 
natural gas including coal-bed methane.8 
 
11.  A strategic plan to promote the use of clean vehicle fuel involves, among other things, a 
critical  examination  of  two  aspects:  (i)  the  economic  least-cost  justification  for  a  project 
considering the objective and the nature of investment; and (ii) the rationale for a project to be 
implemented through the public sector, and later strategies for private sector participation to 
expand the cleaner fuel use. The public sector will need to start addressing the issue of 
vehicular emissions and establish a critical mass of clean fuel using vehicles and the required 
clean fuel supply. Since individuals and private sector fleet operators generally own vehicles, 
the success of fuel switching will greatly depend on the motivation and the decision taken by the 
private sector. The Oil and Gas Law 22/2001 allows the private sector to obtain a license for 
trading natural gas and provides open access to the natural gas transportation network. Thus, 
with a suitable incentive structure, the private sector will eventually be fully involved in the 
supply of clean energy for vehicles.   
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
12.  The TA will assist the Government to prepare the Project for Jakarta. The Project will    
(i) promote the use of cleaner fuel to reduce the pollution caused by vehicular emissions and 
thereby  help  improve  urban  air  quality,  and  (ii)  strengthen  the  air  emission  testing  and 
monitoring framework. The TA consultant will develop a strategic plan on the use of CNG to 
improve urban air pollution, and a pioneer investment plan, which will provide the initial stock of 
cleaner vehicles and the required clean fuel supply to create a critical mass, so that further 
private sector investments can be promoted for lowering vehicular emissions. New investments 
under the Project will be in (i) natural gas transmission pipelines,9 (ii) natural gas distribution 
network and connections to new CNG filling stations, (iii) CNG filling and storage stations, (iv) 
converter  kits  for  existing  gasoline  cars,  (v)  new  CNG-based  buses,  and  (vi)  stations  for 
monitoring ambient air quality and vehicular emissions. The economic and financial analysis of 
the  Project  will  also  help  determine  a  suitable  CNG  price.  The  TA  will  also  assist  the 
Government in developing a formal policy on the improvement of ambient air quality by reducing 
vehicle emissions. The policy can then be adopted by the Government and the Jakarta city 
government.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA will comprise two parts. Part A will prepare the Project using environmental and 
transport data  from Greater Jakarta. Information regarding the supply of natural gas will be 
obtained  from  the  National  Oil  and  Gas  Company  (PERTAMINA),  National  Gas  Company 
(PGN),  and  the  Directorate  General  for  Oil  and  Gas  (MIGAS).  The  analysis  and 
recommendations from previous studies will be summarized, and where necessary, further 
analysis will be carried out to determine if the Project is justified. Other funding agencies that 
have contributed in earlier studies in Indonesia and other developing member countries will also 
be consulted to develop various options.  
 
14.  The plan for clean vehicles and fuel supply for Jakarta should cover all aspects related 
to  new  investments,  including  technology  selection,  technical  specifications,  environmental 
standards, economic and financial analysis, poverty and social impacts, safety requirements, 
environmental impacts, and institutional changes required to expand the use of CNG. The plan 
will include a timetable and projection of the number of vehicles that are expected to substitute 
liquid fuel with CNG. Part A of the TA will also recommend measures to strengthen air quality 
and vehicular emission monitoring. Another important part of the TA will be to prepare a robust 
mechanism to transfer ADB-funded items (e.g., buses and conversion kits) to private sector 
users through financial intermediaries to ensure that the funds are rolled over. The outline terms 
of reference for the consulting services for part A are in Appendix 3. 
 
15.  Part  B  will  assist  the  Government  in  converting  the  MEB  action  plan  to  a  draft 
environmental policy (para. 5). The Government would then (i) obtain the endorsement of the 
related ministries, local governments, civil societies, and agencies; and (ii) formally announce 
the policy for reducing vehicular emissions that will help establish necessary standards and 
guidelines. Part B of the TA will also provide the terms of reference for further studies to finalize 
action plans to implement complementary measures to improve urban air quality, e.g., transport 
planning and limiting emissions from stationary sources. The outline terms and reference for 
part B are also given in Appendix 3. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.   The total cost of the TA is estimated at $758,000 equivalent, comprising $390,000 in 
foreign exchange costs and $368,000 equivalent in local currency costs. ADB will provide 
$600,000 equivalent to finance the entire foreign exchange cost and $210,000 equivalent of the 
local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded 
by the Government of Japan. The Government will finance the remaining $158,000 equivalent 
of the local currency costs. The cost estimates and financing plan are presented in Appendix 4. 
The Government has been advised that providing the TA does not commit ADB to finance any 
ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The two parts of the TA will be implemented over a total period of 8 months, from 
January  to  August  2003.  MIGAS  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  and  PGN  will  be  the 
Implementing Agency for the part A of the TA. A steering committee will be established to guide 
and monitor the project preparatory activities; it will be chaired by MIGAS, with members from 
ministries and agencies, including MOE, National Development Planning Agency, PGN, and 
Jakarta city government. PGN will (i) provide office space, and fulltime professional counterparts 
to work closely with the consultants; (ii) coordinate with the MOE, MIGAS, PERTAMINA,

5 
Research and Development Center for Oil and Gas Technology (LEMIGAS), city government, 
potential financial intermediaries, other external agencies, and other stakeholders to collect 
necessary information and data related to passenger transport and vehicular emissions for 
Greater Jakarta; and (iv) help organize consultation workshops and seminars to finalize project 
design.  
 
18.  Part A of the TA will be implemented over 7 months, commencing in February 2003 and 
ending in August 2003. To implement part A of the TA, a consulting firm will be selected in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements 
satisfactory  to  ADB  on  the  engagement  of  domestic  consultants.  The  simplified  technical 
proposal procedure will be used for selecting a consulting firm on the basis of the quality and 
the cost of the services (quality-and-cost-based selection). Part A of the TA will require 12 
person-months of international and 32 person-months of domestic consultants. The required 
expertise will include (i) international consultants: (a) a CNG-vehicle specialist and team leader, 
(b) an environmental specialist, (c) an energy and transport economist, and (d) a natural gas 
sector and project specialist; and (ii) domestic consultants: (a) an environmental specialist and 
deputy team leader, (b) a transport specialist, (c) an economist, (d) a financial analyst, (e)  a 
natural gas sector specialist, (f) a project specialist, (g) a sociologist and poverty specialist, and 
(h) a financial intermediary specialist. The consultants will be required to prepare inception, 
interim,  draft  final,  and  final  reports,  due  2  weeks,  2  months,  5  months,  and  7  months, 
respectively, after the commencement of services. Tripartite meetings will be held in PGN for 
the presentation and review of the interim and draft final reports. 
 
19.  MOE’s Directorate for Environmental Impact Management for Non-Institutional Sources, 
will be the Executing Agency for part B of the TA. The finalization of the policy will need to 
involve a wide range of stakeholders; therefore, MEB will be closely involved. Part B of the TA 
will be implemented over 7 months, commencing in January 2003 and ending in July 2003. 
Individual consultants will be selected  in accordance with ADB’s  Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB on the engagement of domestic 
consultants. Part B of the TA will require 1 person-month of international and 12 person-months 
of  domestic  consultant  services.  The  international  expert  will  require  knowledge  of 
environmental policy related to vehicular emissions, and the domestic experts will provide inputs 
related to vehicular transport and air pollution. An initial draft policy will be prepared within 3 
months after work commences, a workshop will be held to obtain views from all stakeholders, 
the draft policy will be submitted to MOE 4 months after work commences. Thereafter, the draft 
policy will be endorsed by the local and central governments, and it will be formally announced 
at a seminar within 3 months of receiving the draft policy. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Indonesia for preparing the Clean Vehicle Fuel for Blue Skies Project, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Indonesia: 
The poverty reduction partnership agreement signed in April 2001 states that in the medium-term poverty reduction 
development priorities will focus on three major areas of intervention: growth, human resource development, and 
good governance. The clean energy program in Indonesia contributes directly to environmentally sustainable 
economic growth. Substituting liquid fuels with compressed natural gas (CNG) in vehicles will help mitigate the urban 
air pollution caused by vehicle emissions, and make more liquid fuels available for export. The immediate impact of 
the Clean Vehicle Fuel for Blue Skies Project will be improved air quality for urban residents in Greater Jakarta, 
including the poor. The project will also promote private sector development in the automotive sector. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis        Proposed Classification: Others 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
The poor urban will be among the beneficiaries from the reduced vehicle emissions and hence improved air quality. 
The impact will be reduced respiratory diseases, less demand on the health services, and longer periods for earning 
wages. Secondary data on the poor in Jakarta will be collected, and potential improvement of health conditions and 
employment opportunities of the poor will be estimated. 
 
C.  Participation Process 
Stakeholder analysis: 
The project design will include consultation with the governments, research institutes, private sector, civil societies, 
and potentially affected groups such as vehicle owners, drivers, and passengers. The consultation will include 
identifying factors that influence vehicle user's decision to switch to CNG, relative pricing of CNG, capacity building 
for emission monitoring, promotion of the private sector investment, and opportunities for informal employment that 
could directly benefit the poor.  
 
Participation strategy required: Yes  
Part B will be based on a participatory approach involving the Friends of Clean Emissions (MEB).

2.  Economic Analysis and Poverty Impact Assessment  
4.  The consultants will include an international energy and transport economist, and a 
domestic economist, a financial analyst, and a sociologist and poverty specialist. The tasks 
related to economic analysis and poverty impact assessment will include 
(i)  reviewing the assumptions and methodology used to forecast vehicular traffic; 
(ii)  providing quantitative and qualitative benefits of the project and its components; 
(iii)  carrying out an economic analysis based on ADB ’s Guidelines for the Economic 
Analysis of Projects; 
(iv)  Providing  a table detailing the conversion of economic cost from financial cost of 
the Project and the specific conversion factors used; 
(v)  incorporating  into  the  economic  analysis  an  economic  quantification  of 
environmental impact due to the project following ADB's Environmental Guidelines 
for Selected Industrial and Power Development Projects (1993) and Environmental 
Assessment Requirements of the Asian Development Bank (1998), and Economic 
Valuation of Environmental Impacts: A Workbook (1996). Clearly discuss and 
present the assumptions and methodology; 
(vi)  assessing  the  project's  pro-poor  impact  in  terms  of  ADB’s  poverty  reduction 
strategy; 
(vii)  reviewing and explicitly discussing the assumptions and the economic parameters 
used in the economic analysis;  
(viii)  identifying  and  analyzing  likely  economic  uncertainties  that  could  affect  the 
project's viability, and carrying out a risk analysis using a suitable risk analysis 
model; and  
(ix)  assessing the possibility of the project accessing GEF funds and preparing a 
draft proposal for GEF funding, if eligible. 
 
3.  Investment Design 
 5.  The consultants will include an international natural gas sector specialist, and a domestic 
natural gas sector specialist and a domestic project specialist. The consultant will 
(i)  review the detailed engineering design of project components and provide inputs 
if any, to make it suitably robust; 
(ii)  prepare detailed cost estimates for the project and present the cost estimates in 
ADB format using the COSTAB or an equivalent model; 
(iii)  prepare contract packaging  and  the  draft  bidding  documents,  and  propose 
bidding  procedures  for  items  to  be  procured  under  international  competitive 
bidding:  the  bidding  documents  and  procurement  procedures  must  be  in 
accordance to ADB’s latest guidelines and standard bidding documents;

(iv)  review the project implementation schedule and prepare a Gantt chart showing 
the critical path, and prepare a contract package list and procurement schedule; 
(v)  assess  the  likely  technical  risks  facing  the  project  and  carry  out  sensitivity 
analyses to check the viability of the project under these risks; and  
(vi)  prepare terms of reference, expertise requirements, and person-month estimates

4.  Financial Analysis 
6.  The consultants will include an international energy and transport economist and a 
domestic financial analyst. They will undertake a comprehensive analysis of PGN's financial 
performances and assess the financial viability of the Project. These tasks include the following: 
 
(i)  financial analysis of PGN: (a) review the accounting and financial records of PGN 
for  the  last  5  years;  present  the  key  financial  statements  (viz.,  the  income 
statement, balance sheet, sources and application of funds statement, and a 
summary of financial performance indicators) in ADB format; (b) prepare a succinct 
write-up on the past and present financial performance of the company, bringing 
out the salient features of the performance and issues affecting the performance; 
(c) develop a spreadsheet model in Excel and project PGN’s financial performance 
over the next 5 years, clearly stating the assumptions used; present the projected 
financial performance in ADB format; prepare a concise write-up on the projected 
future financial performance of PGN and state key issues that are likely to affect 
such performance; (d) present PGN’s investment program for the next 5 years; 
present the financing plan for this proposed investment program; examine the 
feasibility of this plan from the financial standpoint; and (e) recommend measures 
that will improve PGN's financial health;  
 
(ii)  financial viability of the project: (a) discuss the most suitable methodology for 
assessing the financial viability of the project and each of its components; compute 
the  project  financial  internal  rate  of  return  (FIRR)  and  comparison  with  the 
weighted average cost of capital (WACC) in accordance with Guidelines for the 
Financial Governance and Management of Investment Projects Financed by ADB 
(2002); and present clearly the assumptions and detailed workings; and (b) assess 
the likely financial uncertainties and risks, and carry out sensitivity analysis to 
check  the  viability  of  the  project  and  its  components  under  these  risks  and 
uncertainties (a risk analysis model to be used); and  
 
(iii)  analysis of PGN’s financial governance and financial management function: (a) 
review PGN’s internal controls to ensure that they are consistent with ADB’s 
Anticorruption Policy (1998), and Anticorruption Policy: Description and Answers to 
Frequently Asked Questions  (2000);  (b)  describe  the  salient  features  of  the 
accounting and financial management practices, including delegation of authority, 
cost control and budgeting processes, and financial performance measurement; 
(c) describe how accounts are audited (both internal and external audit); comment 
on  the  auditing  standards  used  and  adequacy  of  the  auditing  arrangements; 
assess training requirements for auditing; and (d)  recommend  measures  for 
improving  in  the  organization  structure  for  the  financial  functions,  including 
accounting, financial management, and audit.

5.  Environmental and Social Dimensions

(i)  Prepare  an  EIA  for  the  project  based  on  Environmental  Assessment 
Requirements of the Asian Development Bank (1998). The EIA should also (a) 
examine the safety aspects related to high pressure storage of CNG in vehicles 
and filling stations; (b) include adequate provision for environmental and safety 
protection  as  integral  part  of  the  design,  construction,  operation  and 
maintenance;  and  (c)  include  environmental  and  safety  management  and 
monitoring plan. 
(ii)  Prepare a summary EIA using the format given in  Environmental Assessment 
Requirements of the Asian Development Bank; submit a draft summary EIA for 
review, and incorporate any subsequent comments.  
(iii)  Prepare  an  initial  social  assessment  in  accordance  with  ADB  guidelines  to 
determine the likely social and gender effects and potential mitigative measures. 
This includes land acquisition effects and any potential adverse effects on minority 
nationalities. Prepare a social analysis in accordance with ADB ’s Handbook on 
Poverty and Social Analysis, a Working Document.  
(iv)  If significant numbers of project-affected people are identified, develop a land 
acquisition resettlement plan (LARP) in accordance with the principles and format 
set  out  in  the  policy  document  titled  Asian  Development  Bank:  Involuntary 
Resettlement,  and  Handbook  on  Resettlement:  A  Guide  to  Good  Practice. 
Incorporate  in  the  LARP  a  social  analysis  of  the  project,  including 
recommendations  on  (a)  any  changes  necessary  to  the  project  design  and 
implementation arrangements to incorporate social dimensions; (b) any measures 
necessary  to  enhance  benefits  for  or  to  mitigate  adverse  impacts  on  ethnic 
minorities, if any, in accordance with ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples; and (c) 
appropriate socioeconomic monitoring and management plans.  
(v)  Prepare  a  summary  LARP,  submit  a  draft  summary  LARP  for  review,  and 
incorporate any subsequent comments in completing the summary LARP. 
(vi)  Identify ways to ensure active participation of local communities in project design 
and implementation. 
  
6.   Intermediary Financing  
8.  The domestic financial intermediary specialist will perform tasks related to intermediary 
financing, including the following: 
  
(i)  Review  information  related  to  prospective  financial  intermediaries  that  can 
channel  the  assistance  for  the  procurement  of  passenger  vehicles  and 
conversion kits to fleet owners and end users. Review the instruments currently 
available with the intermediaries. 
(ii)  Develop  evaluation  criteria  that  the  intermediaries  would  need  to  satisfy  to 
participate in the project. 
(iii)  Prepare  draft  terms  for  channel  financing  and  discuss  these  with  potential 
intermediaries. 
(iv)  Prepare  a  short  list  of  qualified  intermediaries  with  term  sheets  for  their 
participation.

12  Appendix 3 
 
B.  Part B: Preparation of the Draft Policy for Reducing Vehicle Emissions 
9.  Based on the findings and recommendations included in Friends of Clean Emission's 
(MEB's) draft action plan of February 2002 under ADB-funded regional technical assistance,1 
the consultant will provide the following outputs: 
 
(i)  an update of the air quality status and issues in Jakarta area; 
(ii)  an update of Indonesian policies, regulations, standards, and programs of air 
quality management, with a focus on mobile and stationary sources; 
(iii)  recommendations for changes required in the  incentive and policy structure to 
motivate private sector investment for reducing vehicle emissions; 
(iv)  a draft policy for reducing vehicle emission; 
(v)  a study of and design for the investment needs of the monitoring, investigation, 
and improvement for air pollution sources; 
(vi)  draft  terms  of  reference  for  further  studies  to  help  the  implementation  of 
complementary measures to improve urban air quality, e.g., transport planning, 
limiting emissions from stationary sources; and 
(vii)  a training program for staff in the Ministry of Environment (MOE) and other line 
agencies to improve air quality through the use of cleaner fuels. 
 
1.  Individual International Consultant 
10.  The Executing Agency for part B will be the Directorate for Environmental Impact 
Management for Non-Institutional Sources of MOE. It has the mandate to transform the MEB 
action  plan  into  a  draft  official  policy  on  reducing  vehicular  emissions.  The  international 
consultant  (1  person-month)  will  facilitate  the  consultation  process  among  stakeholders, 
including the MEB members. The consultant will provide inputs from findings of earlier studies 
related to vehicular emissions in Jakarta, and international experience, particularly studies 
under the World Bank-sponsored Clean Air Initiative for Asian Cities. 
 
11.  The  consultant  will  review  the  initial  policy  draft  policy  that  evolves  through  the 
consultation process, and if needed, suggest areas that need to be strengthened to formulate 
the draft policy. The consultant will also participate in two seminars and provide  support in 
assimilating the inputs from participants and taking the process forward. 
 
2.  Domestic Consultants 
12.  Five domestic experts will be engaged (2 person-months each) to assist six working 
groups that will be focusing on (i) ambient air quality monitoring, (ii) fuel standards and quality, 
(iii)  vehicle  standards,  (iv)  inspection  and  maintenance,  (v)  transport  planning  and  traffic 
management, and (vi) institutional development. The domestic experts will prepare discussion 
papers, summary reports, and plans for the working groups. They will help organize the two 
seminars and facilitate information sharing with the participants.  
 
13.  One domestic consultant (2 person-months) will be engaged to draft and edit the initial 
and draft policy document. The documents will be in English and Bahasa Indonesia. Its quality 
should be of a standard for an international audience.
